docs.lead_paragraph: COLONEL CHURCHWARD'S ethnological theories, based on the assumption of a sunken continent in the Pacific, promises to invest that hypothetical piece of prehistoric geography with the romantic glamour attaching to the legend of Atlantis.

headline.main: Mu, the Lost Atlantis of The Pacific Ocean; Colonel Churchward's Conjectures on a Vanished "Cradle Of Humanity" Where Now Only Islands Remain

docs.snippet: ''Enigma Variations'' might be an apt title for the landscape paintings of the contemporary Chinese-born artist Mu Xin, seen in a lean, penumbral exhibition at Asia Society. Even the artist himself is something of a mystery.    Mu Xin is not his r...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Enigma Variations'' might be an apt title for the landscape paintings of the contemporary Chinese-born artist Mu Xin, seen in a lean, penumbral exhibition at Asia Society. Even the artist himself is something of a mystery. Mu Xin is not his real name. He is best known as a writer, not as a painter. His landscapes are complex and arcane in technique. And although they were all produced when he was imprisoned as a political dissident in the 1970's, he denies that they are political art and asks that they be considered without reference to biographical facts.
docs.abstract: Holland Cotter reviews landscape paintings by artist Mu Xin at Asia Society; photos (M)

headline.main: Captive Visions Flourish Amid a Delicate Secrecy

docs.snippet: In the clearest sign so far of the Government's changing position on the army crackdown in June 1989, China's chief spokesman has said he hopes people will forget the matter.    "I don't much want to mention it -- that June 4 disturbance -- and I ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In the clearest sign so far of the Government's changing position on the army crackdown in June 1989, China's chief spokesman has said he hopes people will forget the matter. "I don't much want to mention it -- that June 4 disturbance -- and I hope people gradually forget it," said the chief spokesman, Yuan Mu, in an interview with Chinese television broadcast on Sunday night.

byline.original: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF, Special to The New York Times

docs.snippet: As he sips tea from a battered white ceramic cup, oversized so that he needs to refill it less often, Mu Qizhong speaks slowly -- sometimes painfully, through pursed lips -- and reveals his scars.   It's not as if he pulls up his shirt to show som...
docs.lead_paragraph: As he sips tea from a battered white ceramic cup, oversized so that he needs to refill it less often, Mu Qizhong speaks slowly -- sometimes painfully, through pursed lips -- and reveals his scars. It's not as if he pulls up his shirt to show some surgeon's stitching. Mr. Mu, a large, soft-spoken man seated at the gleaming black conference table in the headquarters of his diversified international company, is much too sophisticated for that. But like many capitalists in China, he is prodded by memories that run rather deeper than a Western executive's indignation at some analyst's sell recommendation.

headline.main: A Tycoon Named Mu: Product of Old China Leading the New

docs.snippet: The first Efforts of fraternity women to prepare their memberships for an effective part in the national defense movement already are under way in Phi Mu, national organization with an enrollment of more than 14,000. Since formation of the nationa...
docs.lead_paragraph: The first Efforts of fraternity women to prepare their memberships for an effective part in the national defense movement already are under way in Phi Mu, national organization with an enrollment of more than 14,000. Since formation of the national defense committee in December, under the chairmanship of Mrs. Frank M. Gentry of Manhasset, it has distributed to both undergraduate and alumnae groups material describing how women can best assist in the national effort.
docs.abstract: Conv plans; natl defense com work discussed

headline.main: Phi Mu Plans Defense Effort; 14,000 Fraternity Women Join In Program That Will Mark Convention This Week

docs.snippet: For the past month, as China's propaganda machine has promoted the nation's new space hero or the latest pronouncements from Communist Party leaders, the Chinese public has seemed more interested in a 25-year-old sex columnist whose beat is her ow...
docs.lead_paragraph: For the past month, as China's propaganda machine has promoted the nation's new space hero or the latest pronouncements from Communist Party leaders, the Chinese public has seemed more interested in a 25-year-old sex columnist whose beat is her own bedroom. ''I think my private life is very interesting,'' said the columnist, Mu Zimei, arching an eyebrow and tapping a Marlboro Light into an ashtray. She added: ''I do not oppose love, but I oppose loyalty. If love has to be based on loyalty, I will not choose love.''
docs.abstract: Internet columnist Mu Zimei, 25, has attracted wide attention in China with her accounts of her numerous sexual experiences; her celebrity, which exploded when she posted explicit online account of tryst with Chinese rock star, has prompted intervention by government struggling to keep grip on social change; her writings have spurred raging debate about sex and women on Internet; Mu, whose forthcoming book was banned, has quit her magazine columnist job and halted her online diary; she comments, interview; map; photo (M)

headline.main: Internet Sex Column Thrills, and Inflames, China

docs.snippet: THE Chinese writer and artist Mu Xin, who was born in 1927, emigrated to the United States in 1982, and lives in Forest Hills, Queens. During the Cultural Revolution (1966-76) in China, he was imprisoned, and for 18 months between 1971 and 1972, w...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE Chinese writer and artist Mu Xin, who was born in 1927, emigrated to the United States in 1982, and lives in Forest Hills, Queens. During the Cultural Revolution (1966-76) in China, he was imprisoned, and for 18 months between 1971 and 1972, was in solitary confinement. For his mental survival he wrote copiously, setting down his thoughts in minuscule characters on paper that was intended to be used by prisoners to write ''self-criticism.'' He stuffed these writings into the lining of his prison clothes. They are unreadable even to someone who knows Chinese, Mr. Mu has said, but stand as testimony to man's basic need for expression and continuous stocktaking.
docs.abstract: William Zimmer reviews landscape paintings and prison writings of Chinese writer and artist Mu Xin on view at Yale University Art Gallery; photos (M)

headline.main: Painting Emotions, As Well as Places

docs.snippet: The late Chinese director Fei Mu produced a 1940 film about Confucius, which vanished in the ensuing years. A copy was found and donated, and after years of restoration, the classic film is about to be seen again....
docs.lead_paragraph: The late Chinese director Fei Mu produced a 1940 film about Confucius, which vanished in the ensuing years. A copy was found and donated, and after years of restoration, the classic film is about to be seen again.
